chapter.title: Context Functions
chapter.para: The context functions provide additional information about where an event occurred. These functions can provide information such as a backtrace to where the event occurred and the current register values for the processor.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Address of the current probe point.

refsection.title: Arguments
refsection.para: None

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: Returns the instruction pointer from the current probe's register state. Not all probe types have registers though, in which case zero is returned. The returned address is suitable for use with functions like symname and symdata.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Mark function as declared asmlinkage

refsection.title: Arguments
refsection.para: None

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: Call this function before accessing arguments using the *_arg functions if the probed kernel function was declared asmlinkage in the source.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Hex backtrace of current kernel stack

refsection.title: Arguments
refsection.para: None

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: This function returns a string of hex addresses that are a backtrace of the kernel stack. Output may be truncated as per maximum string length (MAXSTRINGLEN). See ubacktrace for user-space backtrace.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Return name and address of calling function

refsection.title: Arguments
refsection.para: None

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: This function returns the address and name of the calling function. This is equivalent to calling: sprintf("s 0xx", symname(caller_addr), caller_addr)

refnamediv.refpurpose: Return caller address

refsection.title: Arguments
refsection.para: None

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: This function returns the address of the calling function.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Return first n elements of kernel stack backtrace

listitem.para: number of levels to descend in the stack (not counting the top level). If n is -1, print the entire stack.

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: This function returns a string of the first n hex addresses from the backtrace of the kernel stack. Output may be truncated as per maximum string length (MAXSTRINGLEN).

refnamediv.refpurpose: Fetch a command line argument

listitem.para: Argument to get (zero is the program itself)

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: Returns argument the requested argument from the current process or the empty string when there are not that many arguments or there is a problem retrieving the argument. Argument zero is traditionally the command itself.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Fetch command line arguments from current process

listitem.para: First argument to get (zero is normally the program itself)
Last argument to get (or minus one for all arguments after n)
String to use to separate arguments when more than one.

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: Returns arguments from the current process starting with argument number n, up to argument m. If there are less than n arguments, or the arguments cannot be retrieved from the current process, the empty string is returned. If m is smaller than n then all arguments starting from argument n are returned. Argument zero is traditionally the command itself.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Fetch all command line arguments from current process

refsection.title: Arguments
refsection.para: None

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: Returns all arguments from the current process delimited by spaces. Returns the empty string when the arguments cannot be retrieved.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Returns the current cpu number

refsection.title: Arguments
refsection.para: None

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: This function returns the current cpu number.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Returns the current cpu number

refsection.title: Arguments
refsection.para: None

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: This function returns the current cpu number. Deprecated in SystemTap 1.4 and removed in SystemTap 1.5.

refnamediv.refpurpose: get the file struct pointer for the current task's executable file

refsection.title: Arguments
refsection.para: None

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: This function returns the file struct pointer for the current task's executable file. Note that the file struct pointer isn't locked on return. The return value of this function can be passed to fullpath_struct_file to get the path from the file struct.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Returns the effective gid of a target process

refsection.title: Arguments
refsection.para: None

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: This function returns the effective gid of a target process

refnamediv.refpurpose: Fetch environment variable from current process

listitem.para: Name of the environment variable to fetch

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: Returns the contents of the specified environment value for the current process. If the variable isn't set an empty string is returned.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Return the effective uid of a target process

refsection.title: Arguments
refsection.para: None

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: Returns the effective user ID of the target process.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Returns the execname of a target process (or group of processes)

refsection.title: Arguments
refsection.para: None

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: Returns the execname of a target process (or group of processes).

refnamediv.refpurpose: Mark function as declared fastcall

refsection.title: Arguments
refsection.para: None

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: Call this function before accessing arguments using the *_arg functions if the probed kernel function was declared fastcall in the source.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Returns the group ID of a target process

refsection.title: Arguments
refsection.para: None

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: This function returns the group ID of a target process.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Return function argument as signed int

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: Return the value of argument n as a signed int (i.e., a 32-bit integer sign-extended to 64 bits).

refnamediv.refpurpose: Determines if the current probe point has occurred in the user's own process

refsection.title: Arguments
refsection.para: None

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: This function returns 1 if the current probe point has occurred in the user's own process.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Whether the current probe context is a return probe

refsection.title: Arguments
refsection.para: None

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: Returns 1 if the current probe context is a return probe, returns 0 otherwise.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Return function argument as signed long

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: Return the value of argument n as a signed long. On architectures where a long is 32 bits, the value is sign-extended to 64 bits.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Return function argument as 64-bit value

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: Return the value of argument n as a 64-bit value.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Return the kernel module name loaded at the address

listitem.para: The address to map to a kernel module name

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: Returns the module name associated with the given address if known. If not known it will raise an error. If the address was not in a kernel module, but in the kernel itself, then the string kernel will be returned.

refnamediv.refpurpose: The module name of the current script

refsection.title: Arguments
refsection.para: None

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: This function returns the name of the stap module. Either generated randomly (stap_[0-9a-f]+_[0-9a-f]+) or set by stap -m <module_name>.

refnamediv.refpurpose: The module size of the current script

refsection.title: Arguments
refsection.para: None

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: This function returns the sizes of various sections of the stap module.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Returns the effective gid of a target process as seen in a user namespace

refsection.title: Arguments
refsection.para: None

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: This function returns the effective gid of a target process as seen in the target user namespace if provided, or the stap process namespace

refnamediv.refpurpose: Returns the effective user ID of a target process as seen in a user namespace

refsection.title: Arguments
refsection.para: None

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: This function returns the effective user ID of the target process as seen in the target user namespace if provided, or the stap process namespace.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Returns the group ID of a target process as seen in a user namespace

refsection.title: Arguments
refsection.para: None

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: This function returns the group ID of a target process as seen in the target user namespace if provided, or the stap process namespace.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Returns the process group ID of the current process as seen in a pid namespace

refsection.title: Arguments
refsection.para: None

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: This function returns the process group ID of the current process as seen in the target pid namespace if provided, or the stap process namespace.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Returns the ID of a target process as seen in a pid namespace

refsection.title: Arguments
refsection.para: None

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: This function returns the ID of a target process as seen in the target pid namespace.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Returns the process ID of a target process's parent process as seen in a pid namespace

refsection.title: Arguments
refsection.para: None

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: This function return the process ID of the target proccess's parent process as seen in the target pid namespace if provided, or the stap process namespace.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Returns the session ID of the current process as seen in a pid namespace

refsection.title: Arguments
refsection.para: None

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: The namespace-aware session ID of a process is the process group ID of the session leader as seen in the target pid namespace if provided, or the stap process namespace. Session ID is stored in the signal_struct since Kernel 2.6.0.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Returns the thread ID of a target process as seen in a pid namespace

refsection.title: Arguments
refsection.para: None

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: This function returns the thread ID of a target process as seen in the target pid namespace if provided, or the stap process namespace.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Returns the user ID of a target process as seen in a user namespace

refsection.title: Arguments
refsection.para: None

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: This function returns the user ID of the target process as seen in the target user namespace if provided, or the stap process namespace.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Returns the execname of a target process's parent process

refsection.title: Arguments
refsection.para: None

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: This function returns the execname of a target process's parent procces.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Returns the process group ID of the current process

refsection.title: Arguments
refsection.para: None

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: This function returns the process group ID of the current process.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Returns the ID of a target process

refsection.title: Arguments
refsection.para: None

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: This function returns the ID of a target process.

refnamediv.refpurpose: The name of the given process identifier

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: Return the name of the given process id.

refnamediv.refpurpose: The task_struct of the given process identifier

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: Return the task struct of the given process id.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Returns the active probe name

refsection.title: Arguments
refsection.para: None

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: This function returns the script-level probe point associated with a currently running probe handler, including wild-card expansion effects. Context: The current probe point.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Returns the label name parsed from the probe name

refsection.title: Arguments
refsection.para: None

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: This returns the label name as parsed from the script-level probe point. This function will only work if called directly from the body of a '.label' probe point (i.e. no aliases).

refsection.title: Context
refsection.para: The current probe point.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Return function argument as pointer value

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: Return the unsigned value of argument n, same as ulong_arg. Can be used with any type of pointer.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Returns the active probe point

refsection.title: Arguments
refsection.para: None

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: This function returns the fully-resolved probe point associated with a currently running probe handler, including alias and wild-card expansion effects. Context: The current probe point.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Returns the function name parsed from pp

refsection.title: Arguments
refsection.para: None

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: This returns the function name from the current pp. Not all pp have functions in them, in which case "" is returned.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Returns the process ID of a target process's parent process

refsection.title: Arguments
refsection.para: None

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: This function return the process ID of the target proccess's parent process.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Print kernel stack back trace

refsection.title: Arguments
refsection.para: None

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: This function is equivalent to print_stack(backtrace), except that deeper stack nesting may be supported. See print_ubacktrace for user-space backtrace. The function does not return a value.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Print a register dump

refsection.title: Arguments
refsection.para: None

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: This function prints a register dump. Does nothing if no registers are available for the probe point.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Print out kernel stack from string

listitem.para: String with list of hexadecimal addresses

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: This function performs a symbolic lookup of the addresses in the given string, which is assumed to be the result of a prior call to backtrace.
Print one line per address, including the address, the name of the function containing the address, and an estimate of its position within that function. Return nothing.

refsection.title: NOTE
refsection.para: it is recommended to use print_syms instead of this function.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Print out kernel stack from string

listitem.para: String with list of hexadecimal (kernel) addresses

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: This function performs a symbolic lookup of the addresses in the given string, which are assumed to be the result of prior calls to stack, callers, and similar functions.
Prints one line per address, including the address, the name of the function containing the address, and an estimate of its position within that function, as obtained by symdata. Returns nothing.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Print stack back trace for current user-space task.

refsection.title: Arguments
refsection.para: None

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: Equivalent to print_ustack(ubacktrace), except that deeper stack nesting may be supported. Returns nothing. See print_backtrace for kernel backtrace.

refsection.title: Note
refsection.para: To get (full) backtraces for user space applications and shared shared libraries not mentioned in the current script run stap with -d /path/to/exe-or-so and/or add --ldd to load all needed unwind data.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Print stack back trace for current user-space task.

refsection.title: Arguments
refsection.para: None

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: Equivalent to print_ubacktrace, but output for each symbol is shorter (just name and offset, or just the hex address of no symbol could be found).

refsection.title: Note
refsection.para: To get (full) backtraces for user space applications and shared shared libraries not mentioned in the current script run stap with -d /path/to/exe-or-so and/or add --ldd to load all needed unwind data.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Print out stack for the current task from string.

listitem.para: String with list of hexadecimal addresses for the current task.

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: Perform a symbolic lookup of the addresses in the given string, which is assumed to be the result of a prior call to ubacktrace for the current task.
Print one line per address, including the address, the name of the function containing the address, and an estimate of its position within that function. Return nothing.

refsection.title: NOTE
refsection.para: it is recommended to use print_usyms instead of this function.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Print out user stack from string

listitem.para: String with list of hexadecimal (user) addresses

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: This function performs a symbolic lookup of the addresses in the given string, which are assumed to be the result of prior calls to ustack, ucallers, and similar functions.
Prints one line per address, including the address, the name of the function containing the address, and an estimate of its position within that function, as obtained by usymdata. Returns nothing.

refnamediv.refpurpose: The low level probe handler type of the current probe.

refsection.title: Arguments
refsection.para: None

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: Returns a short string describing the low level probe handler type for the current probe point. This is for informational purposes only. Depending on the low level probe handler different context functions can or cannot provide information about the current event (for example some probe handlers only trigger in user space and have no associated kernel context). High-level probes might map to the same or different low-level probes (depending on systemtap version and/or kernel used).

refnamediv.refpurpose: Return the probe point's function name, if known

refsection.title: Arguments
refsection.para: None

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: This function returns the name of the function being probed based on the current address, as computed by symname(addr) or usymname(uaddr) depending on probe context (whether the probe is a user probe or a kernel probe).

refsection.title: Please note
refsection.para: this function's behaviour differs between SystemTap 2.0 and earlier versions. Prior to 2.0, probefunc obtained the function name from the probe point string as returned by pp, and used the current address as a fallback.
Consider using ppfunc instead.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Return the probe point's kernel module name

refsection.title: Arguments
refsection.para: None

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: This function returns the name of the kernel module containing the probe point, if known.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Chain of processes and pids back to init(1)

listitem.para: Pointer to task struct of process

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: This function returns a string listing execname and pid for each process starting from task back to the process ancestor that init(1) spawned.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Return the signed value of the named CPU register

listitem.para: Name of the register to return

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: Return the value of the named CPU register, as it was saved when the current probe point was hit. If the register is 32 bits, it is sign-extended to 64 bits.

For the i386 architecture, the following names are recognized. (name1/name2 indicates that name1 and name2 are alternative names for the same register.) eax/ax, ebp/bp, ebx/bx, ecx/cx, edi/di, edx/dx, eflags/flags, eip/ip, esi/si, esp/sp, orig_eax/orig_ax, xcs/cs, xds/ds, xes/es, xfs/fs, xss/ss.

For the x86_64 architecture, the following names are recognized: 64-bit registers: r8, r9, r10, r11, r12, r13, r14, r15, rax/ax, rbp/bp, rbx/bx, rcx/cx, rdi/di, rdx/dx, rip/ip, rsi/si, rsp/sp; 32-bit registers: eax, ebp, ebx, ecx, edx, edi, edx, eip, esi, esp, flags/eflags, orig_eax; segment registers: xcs/cs, xss/ss.
For powerpc, the following names are recognized: r0, r1, ... r31, nip, msr, orig_gpr3, ctr, link, xer, ccr, softe, trap, dar, dsisr, result.
For s390x, the following names are recognized: r0, r1, ... r15, args, psw.mask, psw.addr, orig_gpr2, ilc, trap.
For AArch64, the following names are recognized: x0, x1, ... x30, fp, lr, sp, pc, and orig_x0.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Determines validity of register and u_register in current context

refsection.title: Arguments
refsection.para: None

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: This function returns 1 if register and u_register can be used in the current context, or 0 otherwise. For example, registers_valid returns 0 when called from a begin or end probe.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Specify regparm value used to compile function

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: Call this function with argument n before accessing function arguments using the *_arg function is the function was build with the gcc -mregparm=n option.

(The i386 kernel is built with \-mregparm=3, so systemtap considers regparm(3) the default for kernel functions on that architecture.) Only valid on i386 and x86_64 (when probing 32bit applications). Produces an error on other architectures.

refnamediv.refpurpose: The index of this instance in a remote execution.

refsection.title: Arguments
refsection.para: None

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: This function returns a number 0..N, which is the unique index of this particular script execution from a swarm of stap --remote A --remote B ... runs, and is the same number stap --remote-prefix would print. The function returns -1 if the script was not launched with stap --remote, or if the remote staprun/stapsh are older than version 1.7.

refnamediv.refpurpose: The name of this instance in a remote execution.

refsection.title: Arguments
refsection.para: None

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: This function returns the remote host used to invoke this particular script execution from a swarm of stap --remote runs. It may not be unique among the swarm. The function returns an empty string if the script was not launched with stap --remote.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Return function argument as signed 32-bit value

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: Return the signed 32-bit value of argument n, same as int_arg.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Return function argument as signed 64-bit value

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: Return the signed 64-bit value of argument n, same as longlong_arg.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Returns the session ID of the current process

refsection.title: Arguments
refsection.para: None

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: The session ID of a process is the process group ID of the session leader. Session ID is stored in the signal_struct since Kernel 2.6.0.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Return stack back trace as string

refsection.title: Arguments
refsection.para: None

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: Returns a simple (kernel) backtrace. One line per address. Includes the symbol name (or hex address if symbol couldn't be resolved) and module name (if found). Includes the offset from the start of the function if found, otherwise the offset will be added to the module (if found, between brackets). Returns the backtrace as string (each line terminated by a newline character). Note that the returned stack will be truncated to MAXSTRINGLEN, to print fuller and richer stacks use print_backtrace. Equivalent to sprint_stack(backtrace), but more efficient (no need to translate between hex strings and final backtrace string).

refnamediv.refpurpose: Return stack for kernel addresses from string

listitem.para: String with list of hexadecimal (kernel) addresses

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: Perform a symbolic lookup of the addresses in the given string, which is assumed to be the result of a prior call to backtrace.

Returns a simple backtrace from the given hex string. One line per address. Includes the symbol name (or hex address if symbol couldn't be resolved) and module name (if found). Includes the offset from the start of the function if found, otherwise the offset will be added to the module (if found, between brackets). Returns the backtrace as string (each line terminated by a newline character). Note that the returned stack will be truncated to MAXSTRINGLEN, to print fuller and richer stacks use print_stack.

refsection.title: NOTE
refsection.para: it is recommended to use sprint_syms instead of this function.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Return stack for kernel addresses from string

listitem.para: String with list of hexadecimal (kernel) addresses

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: Perform a symbolic lookup of the addresses in the given string, which are assumed to be the result of a prior calls to stack, callers, and similar functions.

Returns a simple backtrace from the given hex string. One line per address. Includes the symbol name (or hex address if symbol couldn't be resolved) and module name (if found), as obtained from symdata. Includes the offset from the start of the function if found, otherwise the offset will be added to the module (if found, between brackets). Returns the backtrace as string (each line terminated by a newline character). Note that the returned stack will be truncated to MAXSTRINGLEN, to print fuller and richer stacks use print_syms.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Return stack back trace for current user-space task as string.

refsection.title: Arguments
refsection.para: None

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: Returns a simple backtrace for the current task. One line per address. Includes the symbol name (or hex address if symbol couldn't be resolved) and module name (if found). Includes the offset from the start of the function if found, otherwise the offset will be added to the module (if found, between brackets). Returns the backtrace as string (each line terminated by a newline character). Note that the returned stack will be truncated to MAXSTRINGLEN, to print fuller and richer stacks use print_ubacktrace. Equivalent to sprint_ustack(ubacktrace), but more efficient (no need to translate between hex strings and final backtrace string).

refsection.title: Note
refsection.para: To get (full) backtraces for user space applications and shared shared libraries not mentioned in the current script run stap with -d /path/to/exe-or-so and/or add --ldd to load all needed unwind data.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Return stack for the current task from string.

listitem.para: String with list of hexadecimal addresses for the current task.

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: Perform a symbolic lookup of the addresses in the given string, which is assumed to be the result of a prior call to ubacktrace for the current task.

Returns a simple backtrace from the given hex string. One line per address. Includes the symbol name (or hex address if symbol couldn't be resolved) and module name (if found). Includes the offset from the start of the function if found, otherwise the offset will be added to the module (if found, between brackets). Returns the backtrace as string (each line terminated by a newline character). Note that the returned stack will be truncated to MAXSTRINGLEN, to print fuller and richer stacks use print_ustack.

refsection.title: NOTE
refsection.para: it is recommended to use sprint_usyms instead of this function.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Return stack for user addresses from string

listitem.para: String with list of hexadecimal (user) addresses

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: Perform a symbolic lookup of the addresses in the given string, which are assumed to be the result of a prior calls to ustack, ucallers, and similar functions.

Returns a simple backtrace from the given hex string. One line per address. Includes the symbol name (or hex address if symbol couldn't be resolved) and module name (if found), as obtained from usymdata. Includes the offset from the start of the function if found, otherwise the offset will be added to the module (if found, between brackets). Returns the backtrace as string (each line terminated by a newline character). Note that the returned stack will be truncated to MAXSTRINGLEN, to print fuller and richer stacks use print_usyms.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Return address at given depth of kernel stack backtrace

listitem.para: number of levels to descend in the stack.

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: Performs a simple (kernel) backtrace, and returns the element at the specified position. The results of the backtrace itself are cached, so that the backtrace computation is performed at most once no matter how many times stack is called, or in what order.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Return the size of the kernel stack

refsection.title: Arguments
refsection.para: None

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: This function returns the size of the kernel stack.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Returns the amount of kernel stack currently available

refsection.title: Arguments
refsection.para: None

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: This function determines how many bytes are currently available in the kernel stack.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Returns the amount of kernel stack used

refsection.title: Arguments
refsection.para: None

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: This function determines how many bytes are currently used in the kernel stack.

refnamediv.refpurpose: The process id of the stapio process

refsection.title: Arguments
refsection.para: None

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: This function returns the process id of the stapio process that launched this script. There could be other SystemTap scripts and stapio processes running on the system.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Return the kernel symbol and module offset for the address

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: Returns the (function) symbol name associated with the given address if known, the offset from the start and size of the symbol, plus module name (between brackets). If symbol is unknown, but module is known, the offset inside the module, plus the size of the module is added. If any element is not known it will be omitted and if the symbol name is unknown it will return the hex string for the given address.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Return the file name of a given address.

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: Returns the file name of the given address, if known. If the file name cannot be found, the hex string representation of the address will be returned.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Return the file name and line number of an address.

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: Returns the file name and the (approximate) line number of the given address, if known. If the file name or the line number cannot be found, the hex string representation of the address will be returned.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Return the line number of an address.

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: Returns the (approximate) line number of the given address, if known. If the line number cannot be found, the hex string representation of the address will be returned.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Return the kernel symbol associated with the given address

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: Returns the (function) symbol name associated with the given address if known. If not known it will return the hex string representation of addr.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Return the process ID of the target process

refsection.title: Arguments
refsection.para: None

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: This function returns the process ID of the target process. This is useful in conjunction with the -x PID or -c CMD command-line options to stap. An example of its use is to create scripts that filter on a specific process.
-x <pid> target returns the pid specified by -x
-c target returns the pid for the executed command specified by -c

refnamediv.refpurpose: The ancestry of the given task

listitem.para: set to 1 to also print the start time of processes (given as a delta from boot time)

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: Return the ancestry of the given task in the form of grandparent_process=>parent_process=>process.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Hex backtrace of an arbitrary task

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: This function returns a string of hex addresses that are a backtrace of the stack of a particular task Output may be truncated as per maximum string length. Deprecated in SystemTap 1.6.

refnamediv.refpurpose: The scheduled cpu of the task

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: This function returns the scheduled cpu for the given task.

refnamediv.refpurpose: The current task_struct of the current task

refsection.title: Arguments
refsection.para: None

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: This function returns the task_struct representing the current process. This address can be passed to the various task_*() functions to extract more task-specific data.

refnamediv.refpurpose: get the path struct pointer for a task's current working directory
The effective group identifier of the task

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: This function returns the effective group id of the given task.

refnamediv.refpurpose: The effective user identifier of the task

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: This function returns the effective user id of the given task.

refnamediv.refpurpose: get the file struct pointer for a task's executable file
The name of the task

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: Return the name of the given task.

refnamediv.refpurpose: get the file struct for a task's fd

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: Returns the file struct pointer for a task's file descriptor.

refnamediv.refpurpose: The group identifier of the task

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: This function returns the group id of the given task.

refnamediv.refpurpose: The max number of open files for the task

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: This function returns the maximum number of file handlers for the given task.

refnamediv.refpurpose: The nice value of the task

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: This function returns the nice value of the given task.

refnamediv.refpurpose: The effective group identifier of the task

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: This function returns the effective group id of the given task.

refnamediv.refpurpose: The effective user identifier of the task

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: This function returns the effective user id of the given task.

refnamediv.refpurpose: The group identifier of the task as seen in a namespace

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: This function returns the group id of the given task as seen in in the given user namespace.

refnamediv.refpurpose: The process identifier of the task

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: This fucntion returns the process id of the given task based on the specified pid namespace..

refnamediv.refpurpose: The thread identifier of the task as seen in a namespace

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: This function returns the thread id of the given task as seen in the pid namespace.

refnamediv.refpurpose: The user identifier of the task

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: This function returns the user id of the given task.

refnamediv.refpurpose: The number of open files of the task

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: This function returns the number of open file handlers for the given task.

refnamediv.refpurpose: The task_struct of the parent task

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: This function returns the parent task_struct of the given task. This address can be passed to the various task_*() functions to extract more task-specific data.

refnamediv.refpurpose: The process identifier of the task

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: This fucntion returns the process id of the given task.

refnamediv.refpurpose: The priority value of the task

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: This function returns the priority value of the given task.

refnamediv.refpurpose: The state of the task

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: Return the state of the given task, one of: TASK_RUNNING (0), TASK_INTERRUPTIBLE (1), TASK_UNINTERRUPTIBLE (2), TASK_STOPPED (4), TASK_TRACED (8), EXIT_ZOMBIE (16), or EXIT_DEAD (32).

refnamediv.refpurpose: The thread identifier of the task

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: This function returns the thread id of the given task.

refnamediv.refpurpose: The user identifier of the task

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: This function returns the user id of the given task.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Returns the thread ID of a target process

refsection.title: Arguments
refsection.para: None

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: This function returns the thread ID of the target process.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Return function argument as unsigned 32-bit value

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: Return the unsigned 32-bit value of argument n, same as uint_arg.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Return function argument as unsigned 64-bit value

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: Return the unsigned 64-bit value of argument n, same as ulonglong_arg.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Return the unsigned value of the named CPU register

listitem.para: Name of the register to return

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: Same as register(name), except that if the register is 32 bits wide, it is zero-extended to 64 bits.

refnamediv.refpurpose: User space address of current running task

refsection.title: Arguments
refsection.para: None

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: Returns the address in userspace that the current task was at when the probe occurred. When the current running task isn't a user space thread, or the address cannot be found, zero is returned. Can be used to see where the current task is combined with usymname or usymdata. Often the task will be in the VDSO where it entered the kernel.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Hex backtrace of current user-space task stack.

refsection.title: Arguments
refsection.para: None

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: Return a string of hex addresses that are a backtrace of the stack of the current task. Output may be truncated as per maximum string length. Returns empty string when current probe point cannot determine user backtrace. See backtrace for kernel traceback.

refsection.title: Note
refsection.para: To get (full) backtraces for user space applications and shared shared libraries not mentioned in the current script run stap with -d /path/to/exe-or-so and/or add --ldd to load all needed unwind data.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Return first n elements of user stack backtrace

listitem.para: number of levels to descend in the stack (not counting the top level). If n is -1, print the entire stack.

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: This function returns a string of the first n hex addresses from the backtrace of the user stack. Output may be truncated as per maximum string length (MAXSTRINGLEN).

refsection.title: Note
refsection.para: To get (full) backtraces for user space applications and shared shared libraries not mentioned in the current script run stap with -d /path/to/exe-or-so and/or add --ldd to load all needed unwind data.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Returns the user ID of a target process

refsection.title: Arguments
refsection.para: None

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: This function returns the user ID of the target process.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Return function argument as unsigned int

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: Return the value of argument n as an unsigned int (i.e., a 32-bit integer zero-extended to 64 bits).

refnamediv.refpurpose: Return function argument as unsigned long

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: Return the value of argument n as an unsigned long. On architectures where a long is 32 bits, the value is zero-extended to 64 bits.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Return function argument as 64-bit value

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: Return the value of argument n as a 64-bit value. (Same as longlong_arg.)

refnamediv.refpurpose: Returns the (short) name of the user module.

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: Returns the short name of the user space module for the current task that that the given address is part of. Reports an error when the address isn't in a (mapped in) module, or the module cannot be found for some reason.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Determines if probe point occurs in user-mode

refsection.title: Arguments
refsection.para: None

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: Return 1 if the probe point occurred in user-mode.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Return address at given depth of user stack backtrace

listitem.para: number of levels to descend in the stack.

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: Performs a simple (user space) backtrace, and returns the element at the specified position. The results of the backtrace itself are cached, so that the backtrace computation is performed at most once no matter how many times ustack is called, or in what order.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Return the symbol and module offset of an address.

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: Returns the (function) symbol name associated with the given address in the current task if known, the offset from the start and the size of the symbol, plus the module name (between brackets). If symbol is unknown, but module is known, the offset inside the module, plus the size of the module is added. If any element is not known it will be omitted and if the symbol name is unknown it will return the hex string for the given address.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Return the file name of a given address.

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: Returns the file name of the given address, if known. If the file name cannot be found, the hex string representation of the address will be returned.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Return the file name and line number of an address.

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: Returns the file name and the (approximate) line number of the given address, if known. If the file name or the line number cannot be found, the hex string representation of the address will be returned.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Return the line number of an address.

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: Returns the (approximate) line number of the given address, if known. If the line number cannot be found, the hex string representation of the address will be returned.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Return the symbol of an address in the current task.

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: Returns the (function) symbol name associated with the given address if known. If not known it will return the hex string representation of addr.

chapter.title: Timestamp Functions
chapter.para: Each timestamp function returns a value to indicate when a function is executed. These returned values can then be used to indicate when an event occurred, provide an ordering for events, or compute the amount of time elapsed between two time stamps.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Kernel HZ

refsection.title: Arguments
refsection.para: None

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: This function returns the value of the kernel HZ macro, which corresponds to the rate of increase of the jiffies value.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Number of milliseconds on the given cpu's clock

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: This function returns the number of milliseconds on the given cpu's clock. This is always monotonic comparing on the same cpu, but may have some drift between cpus (within about a jiffy).

refnamediv.refpurpose: Number of nanoseconds on the given cpu's clock

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: This function returns the number of nanoseconds on the given cpu's clock. This is always monotonic comparing on the same cpu, but may have some drift between cpus (within about a jiffy).

refnamediv.refpurpose: Number of seconds on the given cpu's clock

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: This function returns the number of seconds on the given cpu's clock. This is always monotonic comparing on the same cpu, but may have some drift between cpus (within about a jiffy).

refnamediv.refpurpose: Number of microseconds on the given cpu's clock

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: This function returns the number of microseconds on the given cpu's clock. This is always monotonic comparing on the same cpu, but may have some drift between cpus (within about a jiffy).

refnamediv.refpurpose: Remove an existing stopwatch

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: Remove stopwatch name.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Processor cycle count

refsection.title: Arguments
refsection.para: None

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: This function returns the processor cycle counter value if available, else it returns zero. The cycle counter is free running and unsynchronized on each processor. Thus, the order of events cannot determined by comparing the results of the get_cycles function on different processors.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Number of milliseconds since UNIX epoch

refsection.title: Arguments
refsection.para: None

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: This function returns the number of milliseconds since the UNIX epoch.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Number of nanoseconds since UNIX epoch

refsection.title: Arguments
refsection.para: None

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: This function returns the number of nanoseconds since the UNIX epoch.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Number of seconds since UNIX epoch

refsection.title: Arguments
refsection.para: None

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: This function returns the number of seconds since the UNIX epoch.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Number of microseconds since UNIX epoch

refsection.title: Arguments
refsection.para: None

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: This function returns the number of microseconds since the UNIX epoch.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Kernel jiffies count

refsection.title: Arguments
refsection.para: None

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: This function returns the value of the kernel jiffies variable. This value is incremented periodically by timer interrupts, and may wrap around a 32-bit or 64-bit boundary. See HZ.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Number of milliseconds on the local cpu's clock

refsection.title: Arguments
refsection.para: None

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: This function returns the number of milliseconds on the local cpu's clock. This is always monotonic comparing on the same cpu, but may have some drift between cpus (within about a jiffy).

refnamediv.refpurpose: Number of nanoseconds on the local cpu's clock

refsection.title: Arguments
refsection.para: None

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: This function returns the number of nanoseconds on the local cpu's clock. This is always monotonic comparing on the same cpu, but may have some drift between cpus (within about a jiffy).

refnamediv.refpurpose: Number of seconds on the local cpu's clock

refsection.title: Arguments
refsection.para: None

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: This function returns the number of seconds on the local cpu's clock. This is always monotonic comparing on the same cpu, but may have some drift between cpus (within about a jiffy).

refnamediv.refpurpose: Number of microseconds on the local cpu's clock

refsection.title: Arguments
refsection.para: None

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: This function returns the number of microseconds on the local cpu's clock. This is always monotonic comparing on the same cpu, but may have some drift between cpus (within about a jiffy).

refnamediv.refpurpose: Reads the time in milliseconds for a stopwatch

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: Returns time in milliseconds for stopwatch name. Creates stopwatch name if it does not currently exist.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Reads the time in nanoseconds for a stopwatch

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: Returns time in nanoseconds for stopwatch name. Creates stopwatch name if it does not currently exist.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Reads the time in seconds for a stopwatch

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: Returns time in seconds for stopwatch name. Creates stopwatch name if it does not currently exist.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Reads the time in microseconds for a stopwatch

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: Returns time in microseconds for stopwatch name. Creates stopwatch name if it does not currently exist.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Start a stopwatch

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: Start stopwatch name. Creates stopwatch name if it does not currently exist.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Stop a stopwatch

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: Stop stopwatch name. Creates stopwatch name if it does not currently exist.

chapter.title: Time utility functions
chapter.para: Utility functions to turn seconds since the epoch (as returned by the timestamp function gettimeofday_s()) into a human readable date/time strings.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Convert seconds since epoch into human readable date/time string

listitem.para: Number of seconds since epoch (as returned by gettimeofday_s)

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: 1) Takes an argument of seconds since the epoch as returned bygettimeofday_s. Returns a string of the form

The string will always be exactly 24 characters. If the time would be unreasonable far in the past (before what can be represented with a 32 bit offset in seconds from the epoch) an error will occur (which can be avoided with try/catch). If the time would be unreasonable far in the future, an error will also occur.
Note that the epoch (zero) corresponds to

The earliest full date given by ctime, corresponding to epochsecs -2147483648 is Fri Dec 13 20:45:52 1901. The latest full date given by ctime, corresponding to epochsecs 2147483647 is Tue Jan 19 03:14:07 2038.
The abbreviations for the days of the week are Sun, Mon, Tue, Wed, Thu, Fri, and Sat. The abbreviations for the months are Jan, Feb, Mar, Apr, May, Jun, Jul, Aug, Sep, Oct, Nov, and Dec.

Note that the real C library ctime function puts a newline ('\n') character at the end of the string that this function does not. Also note that since the kernel has no concept of timezones, the returned time is always in GMT.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Convert seconds since epoch into human readable date/time string, with local time zone

listitem.para: number of seconds since epoch (as returned by gettimeofday_s)

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: Takes an argument of seconds since the epoch as returned by gettimeofday_s. Returns a string of the same form as ctime, but offsets the epoch time for the local time zone, and appends the name of the local time zone. The string length may vary. The time zone information is passed by staprun at script startup only.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Return local time zone offset

refsection.title: Arguments
refsection.para: None

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: Returns the local time zone offset (seconds west of UTC), as passed by staprun at script startup only.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Return local time zone name

refsection.title: Arguments
refsection.para: None

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: Returns the local time zone name, as passed by staprun at script startup only.

chapter.title: Shell command functions
chapter.para: Utility functions to enqueue shell commands.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Issue a command to the system

listitem.para: the command to issue to the system

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: This function runs a command on the system. The command is started in the background some time after the current probe completes. The command is run with the same UID as the user running the stap or staprun command. The runtime may impose a relatively short length limit on the command string. Exceeding it may print a warning.

chapter.title: Memory Tapset
chapter.para: This family of probe points is used to probe memory-related events or query the memory usage of the current process. It contains the following probe points:

refnamediv.refpurpose: Returns which node a given address belongs to within a NUMA system

listitem.para: the address of the faulting memory access

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: This function accepts an address, and returns the node that the given address belongs to in a NUMA system.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Human readable string for given bytes

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: Returns a string representing the number of bytes (up to 1024 bytes), the number of kilobytes (when less than 1024K) postfixed by 'K', the number of megabytes (when less than 1024M) postfixed by 'M' or the number of gigabytes postfixed by 'G'. If representing K, M or G, and the number is amount is less than 100, it includes a '.' plus the remainer. The returned string will be 5 characters wide (padding with whitespace at the front) unless negative or representing more than 9999G bytes.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Number of bytes in a page for this architecture

refsection.title: Arguments
refsection.para: None

refnamediv.refpurpose: Turns pages into a human readable string

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: Multiplies pages by page_size to get the number of bytes and returns the result of bytes_to_string.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Program data size (data + stack) in pages

listitem.para: The pid of process to examine

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: 1) Returns the current process data size (data + stack) in pages, or zero when there is no current process or the number of pages couldn't be retrieved.
2) Returns the given process data size (data + stack) in pages, or zero when the process doesn't exist or the number of pages couldn't be retrieved.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Program resident set size in pages

listitem.para: The pid of process to examine

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: 1) Returns the resident set size in pages of the current process, or zero when there is no current process or the number of pages couldn't be retrieved.
2) Returns the resident set size in pages of the given process, or zero when the process doesn't exist or the number of pages couldn't be retrieved.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Program shared pages (from shared mappings)

listitem.para: The pid of process to examine

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: 1) Returns the shared pages (from shared mappings) of the current process, or zero when there is no current process or the number of pages couldn't be retrieved.
2) Returns the shared pages (from shared mappings) of the given process, or zero when the process doesn't exist or the number of pages couldn't be retrieved.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Total program virtual memory size in pages

listitem.para: The pid of process to examine

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: 1) Returns the total virtual memory size in pages of the current process, or zero when there is no current process or the number of pages couldn't be retrieved.
2) Returns the total virtual memory size in pages of the given process, or zero when that process doesn't exist or the number of pages couldn't be retrieved.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Human readable string of process memory usage

listitem.para: The pid of process to examine

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: 1) Returns a human readable string showing the size, rss, shr, txt and data of the memory used by the current process. For examplesize: 301m, rss: 11m, shr: 8m, txt: 52k, data: 2248k.
2) Returns a human readable string showing the size, rss, shr, txt and data of the memory used by the given process. For examplesize: 301m, rss: 11m, shr: 8m, txt: 52k, data: 2248k.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Program text (code) size in pages

listitem.para: The pid of process to examine

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: 1) Returns the current process text (code) size in pages, or zero when there is no current process or the number of pages couldn't be retrieved.
2) Returns the given process text (code) size in pages, or zero when the process doesn't exist or the number of pages couldn't be retrieved.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Test return value for page fault reason

listitem.para: the type of fault to test for (VM_FAULT_OOM or similar)

refnamediv.refpurpose: Fires when a brk is requested (i.e. the heap will be resized)

listitem.para: the length of the memory segment

refsection.title: Context
refsection.para: The process calling brk.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Fires when kfree is requested

listitem.para: address of the function calling this kmemory function
pointer to the kmemory allocated which is returned by kmalloc

refnamediv.refpurpose: Fires when kmalloc is requested

listitem.para: type of kmemory to allocate (in String format)

refnamediv.refpurpose: Fires when kmalloc_node is requested

listitem.para: address of the function caling this kmemory function
type of kmemory to allocate(in string format)

refnamediv.refpurpose: Fires when kmem_cache_alloc is requested

listitem.para: type of kmemory to allocate(in string format)
address of the function calling this kmemory function.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Fires when kmem_cache_alloc_node is requested

listitem.para: type of kmemory to allocate(in string format)
address of the function calling this kmemory function

refnamediv.refpurpose: Fires when kmem_cache_free is requested

listitem.para: Address of the function calling this kmemory function
Pointer to the kmemory allocated which is returned by kmem_cache

refnamediv.refpurpose: Fires when an mmap is requested

listitem.para: the length of the memory segment

refsection.title: Context
refsection.para: The process calling mmap.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Fires when an munmap is requested

listitem.para: the length of the memory segment

refsection.title: Context
refsection.para: The process calling munmap.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Fires when a thread is selected for termination by the OOM killer

refsection.title: Context
refsection.para: The process that tried to consume excessive memory, and thus triggered the OOM.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Records that a page fault occurred

listitem.para: indicates whether this was a write or read access; 1 indicates a write, while 0 indicates a read
the address of the faulting memory access; i.e. the address that caused the page fault

refsection.title: Context
refsection.para: The process which triggered the fault

refnamediv.refpurpose: Indicates what type of fault occurred

listitem.para: returns either 0 (VM_FAULT_OOM) for out of memory faults, 2 (VM_FAULT_MINOR) for minor faults, 3 (VM_FAULT_MAJOR) for major faults, or 1 (VM_FAULT_SIGBUS) if the fault was neither OOM, minor fault, nor major fault.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Attempts at writing to a shared page

listitem.para: the address of the shared write

refsection.title: Context
refsection.para: The context is the process attempting the write.

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: Fires when a process attempts to write to a shared page. If a copy is necessary, this will be followed by a vm.write_shared_copy.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Page copy for shared page write

listitem.para: boolean indicating whether it is a zero page (can do a clear instead of a copy)
The address of the shared write

refsection.title: Context
refsection.para: The process attempting the write.

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: Fires when a write to a shared page requires a page copy. This is always preceded by a vm.write_shared.

chapter.title: Task Time Tapset
chapter.para: This tapset defines utility functions to query time related properties of the current tasks, translate those in miliseconds and human readable strings.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Translates the given cputime into milliseconds
Human readable string for given cputime

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: Equivalent to calling: msec_to_string (cputime_to_msecs (cputime).

refnamediv.refpurpose: Translates the given cputime into microseconds
Human readable string for given milliseconds

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: Returns a string representing the number of milliseconds as a human readable string consisting of XmY.ZZZs, where X is the number of minutes, Y is the number of seconds and ZZZ is the number of milliseconds.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Human readable string for given nanoseconds

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: Returns a string representing the number of nanoseconds as a human readable string consisting of XmY.ZZZZZZs, where X is the number of minutes, Y is the number of seconds and ZZZZZZZZZ is the number of nanoseconds.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Start time of the given task

listitem.para: Thread id of the given task

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: Returns the start time of the given task in nanoseconds since boot time or 0 if the task does not exist.

refnamediv.refpurpose: System time of the task

listitem.para: Thread id of the given task

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: 1) Returns the system time of the current task in cputime. Does not include any time used by other tasks in this process, nor does it include any time of the children of this task.

2) Returns the system time of the given task in cputime, or zero if the task doesn't exist. Does not include any time used by other tasks in this process, nor does it include any time of the children of this task.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Human readable string of task time usage

refsection.title: Arguments
refsection.para: None

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: Returns a human readable string showing the user and system time the current task has used up to now. For example usr: 0m12.908s, sys: 1m6.851s.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Human readable string of task time usage

listitem.para: Thread id of the given task

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: Returns a human readable string showing the user and system time the given task has used up to now. For example usr: 0m12.908s, sys: 1m6.851s.

refnamediv.refpurpose: User time of the task

listitem.para: Thread id of the given task

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: 1) Returns the user time of the current task in cputime. Does not include any time used by other tasks in this process, nor does it include any time of the children of this task.

2) Returns the user time of the given task in cputime, or zero if the task doesn't exist. Does not include any time used by other tasks in this process, nor does it include any time of the children of this task.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Human readable string for given microseconds

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: Returns a string representing the number of microseconds as a human readable string consisting of XmY.ZZZZZZs, where X is the number of minutes, Y is the number of seconds and ZZZZZZ is the number of microseconds.

1 is local operation and 0 is non-local operation

refsection.para: This function is a default filter function. The user can replace this function with their own. The user-supplied filter function returns an index key based on the values in skb. A return value of 0 means this particular skb should be not be counted.

refsection.para: Returns the local tcp port from skb.

refsection.para: Returns the remote tcp port from skb.

chapter.title: Kernel Process Tapset
chapter.para: This family of probe points is used to probe process-related activities. It contains the following probe points:

refnamediv.refpurpose: Get the load average for a specified interval

listitem.para: The load average interval to capture.

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: This function returns the load average at a specified interval. The three load average values 1, 5 and 15 minute average corresponds to indexes 0, 1 and 2 of the avenrun array - see linux/sched.h. Please note that the truncated-integer portion of the load average is returned. If the specified index is out-of-bounds, then an error message and exception is thrown.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Report a pretty-printed load average

refsection.title: Arguments
refsection.para: None

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: Returns the a string with three decimal numbers in the usual format for 1-, 5- and 15-minute load averages.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Does pid descend from target process?

listitem.para: The pid of the process to query

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: This function returns whether the given process-id is within the target set, that is whether it is a descendant of the top-level target process.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Print a report about the target set

refsection.title: Arguments
refsection.para: None

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: This function prints a report about the processes in the target set, and their ancestry.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Fires whenever a new process or thread is successfully created

listitem.para: The TID of the newly created task
The PID of the newly created process

refsection.title: Context
refsection.para: Parent of the created process.

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: Fires whenever a new process is successfully created, either as a result of fork (or one of its syscall variants), or a new kernel thread.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Attempt to exec to a new program

listitem.para: The path to the new executable
A string containing the filename followed by the arguments to pass, excluding 0th arg (SystemTap v2.5+)
Name of the system call (execve) (SystemTap v2.5+)
The arguments to pass to the new executable, including the 0th arg (SystemTap v2.5+)

refsection.title: Context
refsection.para: The caller of exec.

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: Fires whenever a process attempts to exec to a new program. Aliased to the syscall.execve probe in SystemTap v2.5+.

refsection.para: On success, the context of the new executable. On failure, remains in the context of the caller.

refsection.title: Description

refnamediv.refpurpose: Exit from process

listitem.para: The exit code of the process

refsection.para: The process which is terminating.

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: Fires when a process terminates. This will always be followed by a kprocess.release, though the latter may be delayed if the process waits in a zombie state.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Process released

listitem.para: A task handle to the process being released
PID of the process being released
TID of the task being released

refsection.title: Context
refsection.para: The context of the parent, if it wanted notification of this process' termination, else the context of the process itself.

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: Fires when a process is released from the kernel. This always follows a kprocess.exit, though it may be delayed somewhat if the process waits in a zombie state.

refsection.title: Values
refsection.para: None

refsection.title: Context
refsection.para: Newly created process.

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: Fires immediately before a new process begins execution.

Signal being sent to a process

listitem.para: The name of the function used to send out the signal
Indicates whether the signal is sent to an existing sigqueue (deprecated in SystemTap 2.1)
A string representation of the signal
The name of the signal recipient
Indicates whether the signal is shared by the thread group

refsection.title: Context
refsection.para: The signal's sender.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Signal being sent to a process completed (deprecated in SystemTap 2.1)

listitem.para: Indicates whether the sent signal is shared by the thread group.
Indicates whether the sent signal was sent to an existing sigqueue
The name of the function used to send out the signal
The return value to either __group_send_sig_info, specific_send_sig_info, or send_sigqueue

refsection.title: Context
refsection.para: The signal's sender. (correct?)

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: Possible __group_send_sig_info and specific_send_sig_info return values are as follows;

0 -- The signal is successfully sent to a process, which means that, (1) the signal was ignored by the receiving process, (2) this is a non-RT signal and the system already has one queued, and (3) the signal was successfully added to the sigqueue of the receiving process.
-EAGAIN -- The sigqueue of the receiving process is overflowing, the signal was RT, and the signal was sent by a user using something other than kill.
Possible send_group_sigqueue and send_sigqueue return values are as follows;
0 -- The signal was either successfully added into the sigqueue of the receiving process, or a SI_TIMER entry is already queued (in which case, the overrun count will be simply incremented).
1 -- The signal was ignored by the receiving process.
-1 -- (send_sigqueue only) The task was marked exiting, allowing * posix_timer_event to redirect it to the group leader.

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: The tkill call is analogous to kill(2), except that it also allows a process within a specific thread group to be targeted. Such processes are targeted through their unique thread IDs (TID).

Indicates whether to wake up a task in a STOPPED or TRACED state
Name of the process to wake

chapter.title: Errno Tapset
chapter.para: This set of functions is used to handle errno number values. It contains the following functions:

refnamediv.refpurpose: Symbolic string associated with error code

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: This function returns the symbolic string associated with the giver error code, such as ENOENT for the number 2, or E#3333 for an out-of-range value such as 3333.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Formats the return value as a string

listitem.para: Variable to determine return type base value

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: This function is used by the syscall tapset, and returns a string. Set format equal to 1 for a decimal, 2 for hex, 3 for octal.
Note that this function is preferred over returnstr.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Formats the return value as a string

listitem.para: Variable to determine return type base value

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: This function is used by the nd_syscall tapset, and returns a string. Set format equal to 1 for a decimal, 2 for hex, 3 for octal.
Note that this function should only be used in dwarfless probes (i.e. 'kprobe.function(foo)'). Other probes should use return_str.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Possible return value of probed function

refsection.title: Arguments
refsection.para: None

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: Return the value of the register in which function values are typically returned. Can be used in probes where $return isn't available. This is only a guess of the actual return value and can be totally wrong. Normally only used in dwarfless probes.

chapter.title: RLIMIT Tapset
chapter.para: This set of functions is used to handle string which defines resource limits (RLIMIT_*) and returns corresponding number of resource limit. It contains the following functions:

refnamediv.refpurpose: Symbolic string associated with resource limit code

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: This function returns the number associated with the given string, such as 0 for the string RLIMIT_CPU, or -1 for an out-of-range value.

chapter.title: Device Tapset

Extract minor device number from a kernel device number (kdev_t)
Creates a value that can be compared to a kernel device number (kdev_t)
Converts a user-space device number into the format used in the kernel

refnamediv.refpurpose: get the full path

refsection.para: Returns the full dirent name (full path to the root), like the kernel d_path function.

refsection.para: Returns the full dirent name (full path to the root), like the kernel (and systemtap-tapset) d_path function, with a /.

chapter.title: Logging Tapset
chapter.para: This family of functions is used to send simple message strings to various destinations.

refnamediv.refpurpose: evaluate assertion

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: 1) This function checks the expression and aborts the current running probe if expression evaluates to zero. Useserror and may be caught by try{} catch{}. A default message will be displayed.
2) This function checks the expression and aborts the current running probe if expression evaluates to zero. Useserror and may be caught by try{} catch{}. The specified message will be displayed.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Send an error message

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: An implicit end-of-line is added. staprun prepends the string ERROR:. Sending an error message aborts the currently running probe. Depending on the MAXERRORS parameter, it may trigger an exit.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Start shutting down probing script.

refsection.title: Arguments
refsection.para: None

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: This only enqueues a request to start shutting down the script. New probes will not fire (except end probes), but all currently running ones may complete their work.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Send a message to the ftrace ring-buffer

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: If the ftrace ring-buffer is configured & available, see /debugfs/tracing/trace for the message. Otherwise, the message may be quietly dropped. An implicit end-of-line is added.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Send a line to the common trace buffer

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: This function logs data. log sends the message immediately to staprun and to the bulk transport (relayfs) if it is being used. If the last character given is not a newline, then one is added. This function is not as efficient as printf and should be used only for urgent messages.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Send a message to the kernel trace buffer

listitem.para: an integer for the severity level (0=KERN_EMERG ... 7=KERN_DEBUG)

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: Print a line of text to the kernel dmesg/console with the given severity. An implicit end-of-line is added. This function may not be safely called from all kernel probe contexts, so is restricted to guru mode only.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Send a line to the warning stream

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: This function sends a warning message immediately to staprun. It is also sent over the bulk transport (relayfs) if it is being used. If the last characater is not a newline, the one is added.

chapter.title: Queue Statistics Tapset
chapter.para: This family of functions is used to track performance of queuing systems.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Function to record finishing request

listitem.para: the name of the service that finished

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: This function records that a request originally from the given queue has completed being serviced.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Function to record being moved from wait queue to being serviced

listitem.para: the name of the service being moved and started

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: This function records that the previous enqueued request was removed from the given wait queue and is now being serviced.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Function to record enqueue requests

listitem.para: the name of the queue requesting enqueue

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: This function records that a new request was enqueued for the given queue name.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Returns the time reqest was on the wait queue

listitem.para: scale variable to take account for interval fraction

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: This function returns the fraction of elapsed time during which one or more requests were on the wait queue.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Prints a line of statistics for the given queue

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: This function prints a line containing the following

refsection.title: statistics for the given queue
refsection.para: the queue name, the average rate of requests per second, the average wait queue length, the average time on the wait queue, the average time to service a request, the percentage of time the wait queue was used, and the percentage of time request was being serviced.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Amount of time per request service

listitem.para: scale variable to take account for interval fraction

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: This function returns the average time in microseconds required to service a request once it is removed from the wait queue.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Function to reset the stats for a queue

listitem.para: the name of the service that finished

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: This function resets the statistics counters for the given queue, and restarts tracking from the moment the function was called. This function is also used to create intialize a queue.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Number of requests served per unit time

listitem.para: scale variable to take account for interval fraction

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: This function returns the average number or requests served per microsecond.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Fraction of time that any request was being serviced

listitem.para: scale variable to take account for interval fraction

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: This function returns the average time in microseconds that at least one request was being serviced.

refnamediv.refpurpose: length of wait queue

listitem.para: scale variable to take account for interval fraction

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: This function returns the average length of the wait queue

refnamediv.refpurpose: Amount of time in queue + service per request

listitem.para: scale variable to take account for interval fraction

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: This function returns the average time in microseconds that it took for a request to be serviced (qs_wait to qa_done).
